loans.name: Peace

texts.en: Peace used an earlier loan to buy clothes to sell. She is a 35-year-old single mother with three children living in Kasese, Uganda. Peace is solely responsible for looking after her family, and her dream is to educate her children so that they can one day attend university. She has been selling clothes for six years. She got her initial capital from milk sales, her former business. Inadequate capital makes it difficult for Peace to meet different customer demands, a hardship for her business. Peace's goal is to expand the business into new markets. She intends to use the loan to buy clothes to sell before the Christmas season when demand is extremely high.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a food vendor who sells kenkey at the market in Alavanyo, Hohoe. Kenkey is a traditional Ghanaian meal which is made with corn flour and requires fermentation in order to create its unique flavor.It is usually served with a soup, stew, or sauce. It is produced by cooking fermented corn/maize dough wrapped in maize husk and steamed. 

Grace has received education though middle school. She is married and has given birth to 3 children. Her husband is a farmer. Grace has been selling kenkey from a young age, which gives her much experience in the business. Her loan will be used to acquire maize in larger quantities, since she now plans to sell it in a new place near a school. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to plan for her old age.

loans.use: to acquire maize in larger quantities.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
This is Marina, 52, a resident of Batasan, Philippines. She is married to Val, a worker abroad and the father of her children. At this time, she and her husband are working hard to provide income for their family. Marina manages her household while operating her internet cafe business. Services like hers become a need as customers’ demand increases. Her main patrons are students, who require her services for their school assignments. She also has customers who need to rent computers for business purposes, like writing a resume or preparing office documents, as well as those who would just love to surf the net and participate in social networking. Marina earns a minimum of PHP 500 in profit every day.

To help her continue operating her business, Marina is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy additional computer parts and accessories needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Marina hopes to expand her business and wants to help her children. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza is a 39-year-old married mother of four young children from Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in a hog-raising business for almost eight years now. This is the source of her income. Her husband works as a carpenter.

Riza is asking for a loan to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs. With this, she will be able to produce healthy pigs.

In the future, Riza hopes to make her hog-raising business a success. Moreover, she also plans to save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Ma. Tessie

texts.en:
This is Ma. Tessie, 56, a resident of Batasan, Philippines. She is a mother to her daughter. She, together with her husband and child, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to save for the future of her child.

Ma. Tessie operates a community pharmacy store. She retails basic medicine and vitamins to the community. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this, she also sells mineral water for added income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional stocks of medicine and vitamins to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Ma. Tessie hopes to give a good life to her daughter and desires to grow spiritually. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more stock of medicine and vitamins needed in her pharmacy.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 30, is married with three kids. His wife is a tailor and she produces additional income to the family. He supplies car decoration accessories and he has been in business for 3 years. Right now, his monthly from the business is 10000 KES.

He is borrowing a loan of 50000 KES with which he intends to purchase more accessories. He plans to pay back the loan with the anticipated income from the business. 

This is his second loan. He successfully paid his previous loan. He hopes and dreams to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase car decoration accessories.

loans.name: Peace

texts.en: Peace is divorced and has 3 children. She only had basic schooling. Peace is into palm oil production at Alavanyo, Hohoe, which she has done since 2006. Peace uses her income to pay for her children’s school fees and their general upkeep. Peace will use the loan to purchase more palm fruits for more production since she now has customers coming from outside Alavanyo. With the new profits from her expanded business, Peace plans to save for her children’s schooling since she wants them to have higher education.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruits for more production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase different types of fish

loans.name: Mupakasya

texts.en:
Mupakasya is a 26-year-old, married man with three children living in Kasese, Uganda. Six years ago he decided to venture into the clothing business in order to optimally meet his family's needs. Like most responsible fathers, his desire is to see all his children graduating and employed in reputable institutions. 

Different tastes and preferences of his customers coupled with inadequate capital is a major challenge, while his dream is to own a modern boutique adopted to his customers' needs. Mupakasya is requesting a loan to buy clothes to sell ahead of the festive season when demand is very high.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy ingredients, tables, and chairs for her husband's restaurant

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred is a 32-year-old woman. She is single and blessed with two children. Winfred sells mobile phones in Nairobi town, and she has been in this business for seven years, earning a monthly income of 50,000 KES.

This will be Winfred's second loan with KADET LTD, and she plans to use the entire loan to add to her stock of mobile phones and accessories. With the anticipated profits, she wants to built a house and expand her business. 

In the future, she wants to stay happy and be a prosperous businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy mobile phones and accessories for resale

loans.name: Tsevelmaa

texts.en: Tsevelmaa is 40 years old lives with her husband and 2 children in small house in Hovd Province, Mongolia. Her husband Tsendjav works at local market as a salesperson. Her 2 children both go to a local kindergarten. She has been operating her clothing retail business since 2000 at local market. She has built strong relationships with her suppliers and customers, and her business is stable now. She imports clothes from Erlian, China and she needs 3,000,000 MNT to purchase an eco-friendly gas/electric car to reduce her transportation expenses and increase efficiency. She is a hardworking, diligent and honest woman.

loans.use: to purchase an eco-friendly gas/electric car.

loans.name: Gaston

texts.fr: Gaston est un homme de 49 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants. il possède et gère un atelier de fabrication de chaises dans un coin de la ville depuis 20 ans. Avec le crédit sollicite, il désire acheter du matériel de travail (bois, mousse, vis, colle à bois) pour augmenter ses ventes et par la suite réaliser son profit. Les bénéfices générés vont permettre de s'occuper des sa famille d'une part, et d'agrandir son activité d'autre part.
texts.en: Gaston is 49 years old, married, and has three children.  He has owned and run a chair-making workshop in the town for the past 20 years.  He would like to use the loan he has requested to buy raw materials (wood, foam, screws and glue) to increase his sales and profits.  The profits he makes will allow him to take care of his family and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer and plant a half-acre with sorghum and maize

loans.name: Tuzokora Group

texts.fr:
Domine  fait partie du groupe Tuzokora  et   habite à Bujumbura. Elle  a   55 ans et est mariée à  Damien, un cultivateur.  Ensemble, Ils ont  8 enfants  âgés de 30  à 35 ans, dont  6 étudient.

Elle fait le commerce des habits  depuis  15 ans. 

Elle  est à son dixième  crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle  obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et commencer une nouvelle activité : acheter du gravier  à revendre, pour gagner plus. 

Avec les bénéfices de son commerce, elle assure les frais de scolarité des enfants .Elle a payé les frais de santé lors de son hospitalisation.
texts.en:
Domine belongs to the Tuzokora group and lives in Bujumbura.  She is 55 years old and married to Damien who is a farmer.  The couple have eight children aged between 32 and 35.  Six of their children are studying.  

Domine has been buying and selling for 15 years.  She is taking out her tenth loan from Turame.  She will use this Kiva loan to increase her capital and start up a new business: buying gravel to re-sell.  This will make her more money.

With the profits she makes from her business, Domine covers her children's school fees.  She has paid healthcare costs since her hospitalization.

loans.use: to increase her capital and start a new business selling gravel

loans.name: Festus

texts.en:
Festus is a 28-year-old businessman who currently supports his parents and siblings. For the last three years, he has been a small-scale farmer in the Kaptere area. Festus earns a monthly income of 15,000 KES. 

Festus is requesting a 90,000 KES loan to harvest maize, pay to transport his produce to market, and purchase inputs for the next planting season. He has successfully repaid his previous loans. Festus will use the profit from his loan to improve his business. He also plans to save money to educate his siblings. Festus intends to get married in the near future.

loans.use: to harvest and transport maize and purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Rose Maribeth

texts.en:
Rose Maribeth is a 35-year-old married woman and the mother of three young children. She is from Bohol, Philippines. For over 15 years she has been engaged in a seaweed and fishing business together with her husband. This is the sole source of her family's income.

Rose Maribeth is requesting a loan to buy seaweed seedlings, rope, straw, and other materials. She will use her loan to improve her seaweed farming business. In the future, Rose Maribeth hopes to expand her business and save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy seaweed seedlings, rope, straw, and other materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Sanelyn

texts.en:
This is Sanelyn, 35. She is a resident of Batasan, Philippines. Sanelyn is married to Dioleste, a carpenter, and she is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Sanelyn operates a market stall. She sells vegetable products in the community market. She buys a quantity of vegetables and sells it per kilo. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Php (Philippines pesos) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 10,000 Php loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of vegetables to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Sanelyn hopes to be successful in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more vegetables needed in her business.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
This is Zenaida who previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan to buy ready-to-wear clothing and merchandise items to expand the inventory for her store. The earnings from her loan were a big help to provide for the education of her children and for her family's personal, household, and business expenditures. Zenaida also makes sports clothing to earn additional income.

Zenaida is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan to buy additional stocks of supplies and products such as dresses and shirts that she needs in her business. The profit from her loan will definitely help sustain her family's daily needs and provide for the educational expenses of her children. Zenaida looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. In the future, she hopes to be with her children and grandchildren and live a good life. She faithfully meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners that gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of supplies and products such as dresses and shirts that she needs in her business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a forty-two-year-old married woman with eight children living in Kasese, Uganda. For ten years now, she has been selling clothes as well as farming to supplement her earnings.She says that business is usually good during festive seasons and when students have broken off for holidays. However, challenges faced include inadequate money to meet the different tastes of her customers and high rental fees. As a good mother, she desires to educate her children up to the University level as well as to own a modern boutique that meets the quality of her customers. Jane is requesting for a loan to buy clothes to sell ahead of the Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell ahead of the Christmas season.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a 57 year old lady who specializes in running her shop; she also farms as a secondary business. This has been her work for about 3 years and she earns an income of KES 7,000 per month. This is her second loan; she successfully repaid the first. She wants to use the money to buy farm inputs, including seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to be a great farmer.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more inventories of second-hand items to resell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a widow with 3 children. She has received schooling to middle school level. Elizabeth is fishmonger in a small community at Alavanyo, Hohoe, which she has done for the past 7 years. She introduced the selling of cloth and utensils when she lost her husband to enable her to support her three children. Elizabeth uses her income for the financial needs of the family. Elizabeth will use this loan to purchase fish with cash instead of credit that she would have to pay off at the end of the day, as she used to do. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to save so she can get her own working capital to expand her cloth business.

loans.use: to purchase fish with cash instead of on credit.

loans.name: Manana

texts.en: Manana is 56 years old, single and lives with her nephew in the Kutaisi district. Several times, she has requested loans from local financial institutions for her trading business start-up, but without any success. Her loan requests were rejected each time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. The only source of income for the family is the small monthly refugee pension from the local government and the monthly salary earned by Manana’s nephew, who works as a mini-bus driver locally. Besides, Manana works as daily worker seasonally. Manana requested a loan from Credo to start a clothing sales business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisions the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with reasonable conditions for the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of low income. Manana will purchase clothes at wholesale prices and resell them in her district for a profit. It will be hard work for Manana, but according to her estimation, her business will be profitable and will increase the income of her family. The increased profit will be reinvested in her clothing trading business to increase her stock and sales volume. Her family will be able to increase their spending to satisfy their daily needs and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale

loans.name: Manana

texts.en: Manana is 46 years old. She lives with her husband and 2 sons in the Daba Manglisi, Georgia. The family runs an agricultural business. In particular, they have 2 milk cows, whose milk is used for cheese production. Manana milks the cows and produces the cheese which is sold in the capital city at a good price. She is a very hard working woman and is very experienced in her business. Manana is requesting a loan to purchase 3 calves. After purchasing these calves, she will be able to expand her livestock and produce more cheese. This will increase the income of her family and she will be able to improve the living conditions of her family. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase 3 calves

loans.name: Thabu

texts.en:
Thabu is 35 years old, married and a mother of three children. For the last six years, she has earned a living by selling clothes in Malindi. Her income is about KES 7,750 a month. 

Thabu was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer, and she is currently applying for her second loan of KES 30,000 to buy additional stock for her business such as dresses, blouses, trousers, shirts, etc. She will use the anticipated profits to pay her children's school fees and expand her business. Her goal for the future is to continue growing her business so that she can help give her family a good and stable life.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes for her business

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en: Damaris is a 30 year old single lady who supports two members of her family. She has been selling vegetables for a period of about three years with an income of approximately KES 10,000 per month. This is her third loan from KADET LTD and she wants to use it to buy potatoes, tomatoes and cabbages for resale. She hopes to be financially stable and to become a major vegetable supplier.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, tomatoes and cabages for resale

loans.name: Hedije

texts.en:
Hedije, forty-nine years old, is a housewife and her husband is an auto mechanic worker. He is the main source of income for their family. Together they have one young boy. Hedije loves her son very much and spending her time taking care of him as a stay at home mother. At this time Hedije is requesting a loan to renovate her kitchen which is very old and in need of new tiles and water installation.  

This loan will improve their standard of living and is important for sanitary and health reasons as food should be stored and prepared in an environment which is safe, clean and free from dangers of infection or germs. Hedije hopes in the future to be able to find a job and increase her family income so that she can contribute to providing a better education and future. She thanks all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: to renovate the kitchen, to buy tiles and to pay workers for water installation.

loans.name: Elorm

texts.en:
Elorm is married with four children. For the past six years, she has been a food vendor who cooks and sells rice and food at Alavanyo, Hohoe.  Elorm has a junior high school education and is responsible for cooking food in the home. Her husband is a petty trader.

Elorm is requesting a loan to buy bags of rice and a big gallon of oil. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to increase her working capital.

loans.use: to buy bags of rice and a big gallon of oil

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Abbaas

texts.en: Abbas is from Iraq. He is 34 years old, married and has three children. He is the only provider for his family. Abbas is a technician. He specializes in repairing motor generators and other electrical appliances. He established his business in 2005. He has built a good foundation of experience in this field, is well known in the surrounding area, and has an excellent reputation. He is requesting a loan of $2,400 to pay the annual rent for his shop. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to pay the annual rent for his shop

loans.name: Gantulhuur

texts.en: Gantulhuur is 35 years old and lives with her husband and 2 children in a ger in Uvurhangai Province, Mongolia. Her husband Batnasan, 38, is herdsman and also helps his wife to run her dairy business. Her daughter Amarjargal, 16, goes to the local specialty training school and her son Eroolt, 13, goes to a local secondary school. The borrower attended local agrarian training in 2010 and has run her business of organic vegetable growing and sales since. She is also a herdswoman who has produced organic dairy products for years. She is requesting loan of 4,000,000 MNT to purchase equipment and tools to produce more dairy products to sell during winter. She is a hardworking, communicative and friendly woman.

loans.use: to purchase equipment and tools to produce more dairy products to sell during the winter.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 39-year-old married man. He has six children, three of whom are in school. He is a peasant farmer who grows maize. John also has a retail shop as an additional source of income. John started this business in order to have enough income to sustain his family.

He wants a loan of 1,300,000 shillings to buy a motorcycle which will help him to travel from his garden to faraway shops. The motorcycle will ease transportation of his retail commodities, and help him to meet demand on time. It will also reduce John's cost of doing business. His major clients are the residents of his village Kagadi, a town on the outskirts of western Uganda, and residents of neighboring towns.

John hopes to improve the living standard of his family with the proceeds of his agriculture and retail shop. His major challenges are the changing weather conditions, which affect his agricultural production, and the fluctuating prices of agricultural products. John will likely need loans to pay school fees in the future and therefore, he is happy that loans are available from UGAFODE. This will help him to borrow, and then slowly repay, the money to easily educate his children.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to travel between his farm and retail shops

loans.name: Paskali

texts.en: Paskali is a 42-year-old married man with six children living in Hoima, Uganda. He trades in the local brew and has been in business for over ten years. As a responsible father, he desires to see all his children graduate since he never had a chance to go to school, due to the poverty he grew up in. His business is challenged by high license fees, while his plan is to start refining the local brew so as to add value and sell at a higher price. Paskali intends to use the loan to buy local brew to sell.

loans.use: to buy local brew to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy items for general store business

loans.name: Athir

texts.en: Athir is from Iraq. He is 35 years old, married and has three children. He is the only provider for his family. Athir owns a small grocery store selling fruits and vegetables. He established his business in 2009. He has built a good foundation of experience in this field, is well known in the surrounding area, and has an excellent reputation. He is requesting a loan of $2,000 to renovate his shop and to increase his inventory. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to renovate his shop and to increase his inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more sandals and introduce the selling of shoes.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert works for RESTIO ENERGY, a Barefoot Power distributor in South Africa. 

This is his story: 

RESTIO ENERGY Company is a registered company and a leading energy for development consultancy, based in Somerset West, South Africa. The company was founded in 2001 and has since led and participated in numerous consultancy and project development initiatives across the SACD and East African region. RESTIO is understanding energy poverty and developing sustainable solutions to address these realities. RESTIO works principally in the ‘off-grid’ and ‘low-income’ sector covering the fields of renewable energy and liquid fuels for both electric power and thermal energy in order to provide these communities with access to an integrated and sustainable energy solution.

RESTIO ENERGY was set up by Robert. He is a leading development consultant in the African renewable energy industry with specializations in sustainable energy service business models, the productive use of renewable energy, energy and development programme evaluations, and energy project feasibility studies. He has worked with a host of development organizations, including the World Bank, United Nations, Millennium Challenge Account, GVEP-I and GIZ. He holds an MSc degree in Environmental Change and Management from the Environmental Change Institute at Oxford University, as well as a Master of Social Science degree in Social Anthropology. He also serves on the Consumer Working Group of the Global Cookstove Alliance.

The need for affordable and clean energy among the South Africans not connected to the grid in the townships was the idea behind starting RESTIO and the commitment to promoting original, financially sustainable and accessible solutions to a range of energy related problems and challenges. According to Robert, “We understand that energy is an essential element in achieving sustainable development and we aim to understand and address the obstacles impeding the successful delivery. We focus on a broad range of market opportunities, from working with those facing energy poverty to more mainstream opportunities in commercial, agricultural and industrial arenas. Working with a client profile including private, public and non-governmental organizations, we develop, promote and distribute energy solutions that inform, present income-generating opportunities, and offer convenience and value for money.

"We aim to reduce the use of candles and paraffin lanterns, which will in turn reduce accidental fires as well as accidental ingestion of paraffin. We also believe that current illumination options, in addition to the dangers, are more expensive in the long-run than Barefoot Power products." 

Importantly, the presence and use of Barefoot Power products within these rural households will provide an invaluable demonstration of the effectiveness and performance of PV-based lighting products in communities where such products currently have very little traction. This will be used to further stimulate the demand for these products.

The loan will be used toward the cost of procurement of 1,800 Firefly Mobile Lamps from Barefoot Power. This will assist with the cash flow requirements for the purchase and distribution of the Firefly Mobile Lamps to individuals and communities in six provinces in South Africa, supported by a government contract through the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform (DRDLR). Through it, RESTIO will be in a position to reach 1,700 people in remote areas through a coordinated formal distribution as dictated by the DRDLR.

In order for the Firefly Mobile Lamps to become increasingly accessible to all markets, RESTIO requires economies of scale, so the more people who benefit from the use thereof, the more this will contribute to RESTIO building a sustainable mode of distribution in order to grow the market.

video.title: Kiva Borrower Robert from South Africa

loans.use: To buy and sell Barefoot Power's solar lighting products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is still married to Margret, and he says that his wife and children are all fine. He is still in the butchery business, and from the last loan, his income has increased to 10,000 KES (Kenyan shillings).

This marks his third borrowing from KADET LTD after successfully repaying the previous loans. He wants to use this loan to buy building materials, as he plans to expand the space that his business is in. This will allow him to bring in more stock and also venture into cooking the meat for his customers as well. 

He hopes to give his family a quality life and education.

loans.use: To buy building materials to expand the space of his butcher shop.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy, aged 36 years, is married, and has four children and two additional dependents. All are at school.  She is taking a loan of ugx.1,000,000 in order to buy fertilizers to increase her farming output.

She started this business in 2001 to help her earn a living and meet her family needs.  Her business is tea planting and she has a market at the factory.

She hopes to establish herself so that she can meet school fee needs in the future. 

Her challenges are natural calamities such as hail stones and drought that affect the yield.

In the future, if she gets support, she expects to purchase irrigation pumps to check the drought since she is near the swamp. 

She is a hardworking woman because has been able to pay back her previous loan.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizers.

loans.name: Tane

texts.en:
Tane, age 44 and widowed, was left upon her husband's death some time ago to raise all six of her children on her own. "I struggle financially and emotionally as well," she told us. She has been photographed here next to her youngest child while he was sleeping. 

She and her children live in a little town in the northern Albania, and she buys and sells used items "just for survival," she said. "It breaks my heart seeing my children not having enough food and myself not being able to do something about it," she said tearfully. "I hope that someday my prayers will be answered and my kids will make a better life for themselves. Until then, I am left with my only choice: taking care of them as well as I can."

She is requesting a loan of approximately $975, which will enable her to add a larger inventory of used items to offer for sale.

Kindly note that Tane has been a VisionFund Albania client for long time now and this loan is her sixth one from the same institution.

loans.use: to add a larger inventory of used items to offer for sale

loans.name: Zhora

texts.en:
Zhora is a teacher in the secondary school of Gandzaqar village. He lives with his mother and wife. As his monthly salary isn't enough to cover his family's basic needs, Zhora is involved in an agricultural business as well. He keeps three pigs and 20 chickens. Together with his mother and wife, Zhora also grows peach, pear, apple and nut trees. Agriculture helps them to have a stable income and cover their basic costs.

Zhora has applied for this loan to expand his farm. With the requested amount Zhora, will purchase two pigs and forage for feeding them. This will help him increase his income and improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to pay for two pigs and forage for feeding them.

loans.name: Remy

texts.en:
This is Remmy, he previously accessed an 10,000 PHP loan that he utilized to purchase more fruits needed for his business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan that he will use to buy different fruits for his business. More items to sell will result in better profit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain the daily needs and educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Remy dreams that his children will finish their studies. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week. This is where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more fruits that he will sell in the market.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine, age 44 and widowed, sells new clothes and shoes to earn her living. She has been engaged in this business for the past 11 years and earns a monthly income of KES 25,000. She lives in Kisumu city and has two children, ages 12 and 24.

She has applied for a loan from KADET Ltd which she will use to purchase more stocks of clothes and shoes to offer for sale, as well as to establish a new premise for her business. She plans to use the profit expected from this loan to pay school fees for her children and to buy food for the family.

She dreams of becoming a successful entrepreneur in the region.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of clothes and shoes to offer for sale and to establish a new premise for her business

loans.name: Koba

texts.en:
Koba, age 46, runs a family agricultural business. He lives in the village of Ruisi with his wife, his retired parents, and two children. 

Koba leads the agricultural business of the family. The family has a calf and a milk cow, whose milk is used in cheese products. The cheese is sold locally. They also have a plot of land where tomatoes, cabbages, maize, and onions are grown. Koba’s father works as an artisan and gets a monthly income, which allows him to help supplement the income from the family business.

Koba owns a tractor. He works with it on land cultivation in his district. For this work he is paid by the local farmers. Koba has requested credit to fix the engine of the tractor, as the engine is out of order at the moment. After the renovation, Koba will be able to continue working on the tractor and receive an income. His goal is to improve and support the well-being of his family.

loans.use: to pay to fix the engine of the tractor

loans.name: Natalya

texts.ru:
Мудро вложив предыдущий кредит КИВА в развитие своего дела,  Наталия смогла увеличить доход на 1 500 гривен. 
В этот раз Наталия надеется вложить дополнительные средства в размере 20 000 гривен в закупку семян и горшков для цветов. За счет расширения ассортимента в магазине Наталия надеется привлечь больше клиентов.
texts.en: Having wisely invested her previous Kiva loan into developing her business, Natalya was able to increase her income by 1,500 Ukrainian Hryvnya. This time, she hopes to invest additional funds in the amount of 20,000 Hryvnya in buying seeds and flower pots. Natalya hopes that by expanding the range of goods she sells in her shop, she will be able to attract more customers.

loans.use: to buy seeds and flower pots

loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima is a 32-year-old very hard working and talented woman. She is a mother of 2 sons and 2 daughters. Her husband is a taxi driver. One daughter is studying in 9th class while the other one is in the 7th class. Both of her sons are less than 5 years old.

Saima has been running a beauty parlor for the past two years. She has gotten a lot of appreciation through her work. She is very talented and knows the art of makeup very well. People prefer her services for bridal makeup. She makes enough to support her family well.

Due to an increase in the number of customers, she requires more beauty products such as makeup kits, hair dryers, facial products etc. For this, she has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to meet the requirements of her parlor, which ultimately helps her in generating more income. 

Saima desires to expand her parlor and intends to spend part of her income on the improvement of her house.

Note: In the picture Saima holds a pass book in her hand.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products such as hair dryers, makeup kits etc for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Meri

texts.en:
Meri, age 55, runs an agricultural business. She lives with her son in the Tsalka district. Meri has a milk cow, whose milk she sells locally in an open market at a good price. In addition, she has half a hectare of agricultural land, where potatoes are grown. She sells the harvested potatoes locally. Meri is a very hard-working woman and does her best to ensure a good harvest. 

She has requested a loan for purchasing two milk cows. After purchasing these additional milk cows, she will be able to produce more dairy products to sell at a good price. This will increase the family income and will improve the living conditions of the family. 

Meri is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase two milk cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy grocery items, toiletries, and beverages to offer for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Koba

texts.en: Koba is 48 years old. He is single and lives alone in the Borjomi District. Koba earns his living through an agricultural business. In particular, he owns 3 milk cows and 6 calves. Besides this, Koba grows potatoes and carrots on his agricultural land. He is a very hard-working man, with a rich experience in his work. Koba is requesting credit to start-up a trade business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative from Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provisioning business start-ups and re-startups with credit on soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With the received credit, Koba will purchase a mini-bus to trade his harvested potatoes. This will save the costs of transportation. Besides this, he will purchase various greengrocery products from local farmers at wholesale prices and sell them in nearby towns with a price mark-up. This new business initiative will increase Koba's monthly income. His living conditions will improve and in the future, he will have enough income to access regular credit products available in his country’s capital market, if needed.

loans.use: to purchase a mini-bus for trading

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion is a 68-year-old married woman and a mother of ten grown up children from Ubay, Bohol. She is engaged in a food vending business, selling home cooked food to the people in her place. 
Asuncion is asking for a loan to buy additional ingredients such as flour, sugar, butter, cooking oil and others. With these, she will be able to cook and sell more, thus augmenting her sales and income.
In the future, Asuncion hopes of making her business a success. She also wants to save money for future use.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients such as flour, sugar, butter, cooking oil and others

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more tomatoes and other vegetables for expanding her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
This is Rose. She previously accessed an 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business. The more items she has on display and available onhand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Rose dreams of giving her children a good quality education and hopes to expand her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work as well as to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizers for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Bardhe

texts.en:
Bardhe, age 57, buys and sells used items to earn an income. She is a member of the vulnerable ethnic minority of Egyptian Albanians. She is married, has three children, and lives in a district in northwest Albania. 

"Being vulnerable doesn’t mean that you don’t work hard," she told us. "The majority of us in our community haven’t had any schooling for various reasons, yet we knew our talents and we used them to earn an income. Nowadays, almost all of the children of our community attend school, and I believe they will have a better chance of getting ahead in life compared to their parents," she added with a smile.

Bardhe is requesting a loan in order to buy used items, such as shoes, to offer for sale.

loans.use: to buy used items, such as shoes, to offer for sale

loans.name: Adrine

texts.en:
Adrine is married with 4 children, all of whom are in school, as well as 3 dependents, whose parents passed on and who are also enrolled in school. She is requesting a loan to increase her trade in second-hand clothes. She works every market day in various markets, except on Sundays. 

Adrine started her business in 2000 to help her provide basic necessities for her household. Her husband is a builder, and he does not earn enough income to adequately meet the family's needs. Adrine's clients are mostly students from the nearby university and low-income residents of the neighboring areas. Because most people want to buy themselves some clothes for Christmas, she hopes to earn more income this season, which will enable her to save some money for her children's school fees during the next academic year.

Adrine is a very hard-working woman who loves what she does. However, she does face some challenges in her business. Some time ago, she was in a terrible accident that left her unable to walk properly. She now hires someone to help her carry the bales of clothing to the marketplaces, which is expensive. Her business is also affected by weather changes. She encourages other people to always take a risk if they want to succeed.

loans.use: To buy bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Irina

texts.ru: Ирина торгует женской одеждой на рынке. Благодаря КИВА кредиту в прошлы раз Ирина увеличила ассортимент товара и получила дополнительную прибыль. В этот раз Ирина также просит предоставить ей кредит на закупку товара. В этом году зима выдалась холодной и покупательский спрос на теплые зимние вещи вырос. Ирина надеется получить дополнительную прибыль и улучшить свои жилищные условия. Бизнес является единственным источником дохода для Ирины и ее 5-ти летнего сына.
texts.en: Irina sells women's clothing in the market. Thanks to her last Kiva loan, Irina has increased the range of products she sells and earned additional income. This time, Irina is requesting a loan to purchase goods. This year the winter has been cold, and customer demand for warm winter clothing has gone up. Irina hopes to earn additional income and improve their living conditions. This business is the only source of income for Irina and her 5-year-old son.

loans.use: to buy winter clothing for sale.

loans.name: Natalya

texts.ru:
Наталья замужем. У нее двое детей, которые ходят в школу. Вместе с мужем она ведет бизнес.
 
Наталья занимается выращиванием овощей на протяжении 8 лет.  Она имеет свой большой участок земли, который позволяет развиваться и строить новые теплицы.  Наталья общительная, трудолюбивая и не боится трудностей.  Она также подрабатывает в отделе социальной помощи и предоставляет услуги парикмахера на дому. Но основной доход семьи приносит бизнес.

Наталья просит предоставить ей кредит в сумме 10000 гривен на покупку пленки и семян.
texts.en:
Natalya is married. She has two children who go to school. She and her husband work in business together.

Natalya has been growing vegetables for eight years. She has a large parcel of ​​land which she is developing and where she is building a greenhouse. Natalya is sociable, hardworking, and not afraid of difficulties. She also works part-time for the Department of Social Welfare and she works as a hairdresser in her home.  However, the agricultural business is the family's main source of income. 

Natalia is asking for a loan of 10,000 hryvnia to buy seeds and plastic film for her greenhouse.

loans.use: to buy seeds and plastic film for her greenhouse

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Silvia Elizabeth

texts.es: Silvia de 28 años vive junto a su esposo y su hijo. Ella se dedica  a la agricultura de los principales granos básicos como son: maíz y frijol. Después de sacar la cosecha  comercializa una parte de su cultivo para poder suplir las necesidades de su hogar que cada día son mayores. Ella es una mujer muy emprendedora y admirable, no se cansa de realizar esta actividad ya que para ella, lo más importante en la vida es ganarse el pan de cada día dignamente con el trabajo de sus manos y el sudor de su frente. Ha trabajado toda su vida en la agricultura y es así como ha logrado sobrevivir, puesto que no cuenta con otra fuente de ingresos diferente a la agricultura. Como toda mujer emprendedora y visionaria ha tomado la decisión de acercarse a INTEGRAL ya que la fecha para empezar las siembras se aproximan y quiere estar preparada y espera recibir un prestamos: para invertir en la compra de los insumos agrícolas como: semillas, insecticidas, abonos, u otros para comenzar la siembra lo más antes posible y poder cosechar los frutos de su esfuerzo. Confía plenamente que obtendrá una cosecha abundante la cual la cual le permitirá mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Silvia, 28, lives with her husband and her son.  She is a farmer who cultivates grains such as corn and beans.  After the harvest, she sells a portion of her crops so that she can meet the growing needs of her household.  Silvia is an enterprising and admirable woman who never tires of working, because for her, the most important thing is to provide the daily sustenance to her family in a decent manner, with the work of her hands and the sweat of her brow.  

Silvia has worked all of her life in agriculture, and this is how she has managed to survive, given that she has no source of income outside of farming.  As an enterprising and visionary woman, she decided to approach INTEGRAL, because the season to begin planting is approaching and she wants to be prepared.  She hopes to receive a loan so that she can invest in the purchase of farming supplies such as seeds, insecticides, fertilizers, and other supplies.  This way she can start planting as soon as possible, and she will reap the harvest resulting from her efforts. She has full confidence that she will get an abundant harvest which will allow her to improve the quality of life for herself and her family.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies such as: seeds, insecticides, organic fertilizers, and other supplies

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is 48 years old and married to Benjamin who contributes to the family’s total income. The couple has three children. For the past two years, Veronica has been a farmer and she earns approximately 3,000 KES per month.

Veronica is requesting her second loan with KADET LTD to buy farm inputs including kale and spinach seedlings and fertilizer. She successfully repaid her previous loan. Veronica hopes to give her children a good education and quality life.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as kale and spinach seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Rovshan

texts.en: Rovshan is 41 years old. He lives with his wife, son, and mother in a small village in Bolnisi district. His mother is provided with a retirement pension. Rovshan is involved in agricultural activities. Specifically, he has 2 cows, whose milk is used in dairy products, and a calf. He also has a plot of farmland, where he sows maize and onions. He sells his harvested products and dairy products locally in an open market at a good price. Rovshan is very hard-working and has a rich experience in his business. He has requested a loan for purchasing sheep, in order to expand his livestock business. He hopes that this loan will increase the family's income so they can improve their living conditions. Rovshan awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy charcoal and Irish (white potato) to sell

loans.name: Gandiimaa

texts.en: Mrs.Gandiimaa is 37 years old and the female head of the household. She lives with her 4 children in a Ger in the Hentii province of Mongolia. Her older son Chinbat, aged 19, goes to university, while Naranhand (17), Bumbayasah (11), and Buyantogtoh (10) go to local schools. Gandiimaa has been renting her workplace and running her business of a religious articles retail store for a year now, and she has already built closer relationships with her suppliers and customers. She is now requesting 2'000'000MNT to purchase insulation material and felt cover for her Ger in order to stay warm during the harsh, cold Mongolian winter. Gandiimaa is a hardworking, open-minded and welcoming person.

loans.use: to purchase insulation material and felt cover for her Ger in order to stay warm during the harsh, cold Mongolian winter

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is 66 years old. He lives with his wife in Dighomi distrisct, near the capital city. George is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, he has a greenhouse, where tomatoes and cucumbers are grown. He sells the harvested products at a good price in the capital city. George is very hard working and has a rich experience in his business. George requested a loan for purchasing wood and fertilizers. After buying the wood the greenhouse will be heated properly and after fertilizing he will ensure a good harvest. This will increase his income and with increased income the pair can improve their living conditions. George awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase wood and fertilizers for the greenhouse

loans.name: Aiza

texts.en:
This is Aiza, 45, resident of Batasan, Philippines. Aziza is a mother of 5 children and married to Salic, a vendor. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her family.

Aiza operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, and sell them piecemeal with a little profit. Products are belts, wallets, chargers, remote controls and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Aiza hopes to give her children a good and quality education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for different products like wallets, belts, chargers etc. needed in her business.

loans.name: Terrylyn

texts.en:
This is Terrylyn, resident of Batasan, Philippines. She is married to Elbert, a driver and father of her children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Terryly retails processed meat products. What she basically does is buy processed meat products from wholesalers and then sells them per piece/pack with a profit. Products can range from ham, hotdogs, processed pork and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options Terrylyn offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She is also working as a cutter in a tailoring shop. She earns a minimum of PHP300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP18, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of frozen products like hotdogs, ham, stuffed meat and other frozen meat products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Terrylyn dreams of having their own house and hopes to have a stable job and business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, which is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more quantities and varieties of frozen products like hotdogs, ham, stuffed meat and other frozen meat products to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Natalla

texts.en:
Natalla, 49, is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Alexander, self-employed, and has children. She and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. Natalla works hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses.

Natalla operates a business buying and selling slippers. Customers are attracted to buy due to her low prices and the many options she offers. Natalla's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Natalla is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan to buy additional stock to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Natalla hopes to be able to expand her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more slippers

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Myagmarjav

texts.en:
Mrs. Myagmarjav, 43 years old, lives with her husband and 2 children in a rental apartment in Orhon province, Mongolia. Her husband, Lhagva-Ochir, is 43 years old and earns a salary. Her 2 children, Jargalmaa, age 20, and Bumanbayar, age 19, are both university students.

Myagmarjav has been running her grocery store since 2003 at a local market and she has now moved to a rental workplace to get closer to customers. She has built a strong relationship with her suppliers and customers over the years. She is requesting a loan of 3,900,000 MNT to purchase construction material and to install a new heating system in order to reduce heat loss. Myagmarjav is hardworking, welcoming and responsible.

loans.use: to purchase construction material and to install a new heating system to reduce heat loss

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas, 28 years old, lives in Kitale county, Kenya, where he has been practicing mixed farming for the past three years. He produces milk and horticultural and poultry products which he sells at the local market.

Nicholas is requesting a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. The cow will give him more produce and enable him to earn extra income which will help boost his living standards and to pay for his children's schooling.

Nicholas' major farming challenges are inadequate capital, pests and diseases. He is thankful to Juhudi Kilimo for funding him with the loan.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Risa

texts.en:
This is Risa, 28, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Alejandro, a mechanic, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. She is working hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

Risa operates and owns an auto repair shop. Her husband is the main mechanic, while she handles finances, accounts, inventories and promotion. They offer repair, check-ups and beautification of all types of cars and jeepneys, and any type of vehicle that will be referred to them.

To help Risa continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan. She will use the loan to buy supplies like wiring, putty paint and other supplies of the like. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Risa dreams of being successful in her business and hopes to have a good life with her family. She faithfully meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for equipment needed in her auto repair shop.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Sika

texts.en: Sika is married and has 1 child. She has received schooling only to the Junior High School level. Sika has had training in pharmacy and sells drugs in Alavanyo, Hohoe. Her husband is a petty trader. Sika uses her income to assist with the housekeeping. She will use this loan to purchase a variety of drugs which have been demanded. Sika plans to use the new profits from her expanded business to save for her child's education.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of requested drugs

loans.name: Sabir

texts.en: Sabir, 42 years old, lives with his wife in the Bolnisi district, where he is involved in agricultural activities. Sabir has a milk cow and 90 sheep. He also has 0.3 hectares of agricultural land, where he grows maize, haricots and potatoes. He sells the harvested products locally at a good price. Sabir is a very hardworking man and does his best to insure a good harvest. He has requested a loan to purchase additional sheep in order to expand his livestock and increase the family's income. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora, 28 years old, lives in Georgia's Khashuri district. She shares her home with her husband, mother-in-law and 10-year-old daughter. Nora’s mother-in-law is a pensioner. The family earns a living by running a small dairy farm. Nora makes cheese with their cow's milk and sells it at the local open market. The family grows different kinds of vegetables on their land. Nora works hard to set aside some savings and to improve her family's living conditions.

Nora is requesting this loan to buy an additional cow so that she can produce and sell more cheese and earn a greater profit. She will use these profits to invest in her business and to provide her family with a better life.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Carmelo

texts.en: Carmelo is a fisherman from Ubay, Bohol. He has been in the fishing business for more than 20 years. Carmelo is asking for a loan to buy materials such as nets, hooks, lead weights and buckets, for fishing. This equipment will allow him to enhance and augment his daily catch thus giving him more fish to sell in the market. Carmelo hopes to expand his fishing business in the future. He also wants to save money for his children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy materials such as nets, hooks, lead weights and buckets

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice sells locally made doughnuts, which are called “bofrot”, in Alavanyo, Hohoe. Beatrice has received basic education. She is married with four children and her husband is a carpenter. Beatrice has been selling doughnuts so that she can assist her husband with their basic needs at home. Her loan will be used to buy flour, oil, sugar and margarine, which are the main ingredients for frying doughnuts. She hopes to save part of the new profits from her business and use part to give more nutritional food to her family so that her children can be brilliant in school.

loans.use: to buy flour, oil, sugar and margarine, which are the main ingredients for frying doughnuts.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
This is Josephine, 42, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Crisanto and is a mother. She, together with her husband, manages her household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Josephine operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals in the evenings when all family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to use cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and meats cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products such as meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings, and frozen food products. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Josephine hopes that her business will expand soon and dreams to have a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. There she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken and vegetables and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience prepares and sells cassava dough in the community, of Alavanyo, Hohoe. Cassava dough is made from fresh cassava. Cassava dough is used in preparing banku and gari which are local Ghanaian dishes. The cassava is peeled, grated into flour, put into a sack and pressed for two or three days for starchy water to drain out of it. After three days, you have a dry, tightly pressed together clump of cassava.  

Patience is not educated.  She is married and expecting a baby. Her husband is into oil palm production.  Patience has been selling cassava dough since 2008. She helps her husband with some basic home bills. Her loan will be used to buy fresh tubers of cassava from her suppliers on a cash basis and not on a credit basis as she used to. She hopes to save her new profits from her business for her newborn baby.

loans.use: to buy fresh tubers of cassava from her suppliers on a cash basis and not on a credit basis.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Kujtim

texts.en:
Kujtim is 23 and married. He is the father of 4 children. His wife is a housewife. Kujtim works at a water supply company with a very low salary. They live under extremely poor and unhealthy conditions. Kujtim’s family always feels cold and gets sick in winter due to the cold weather conditions. This is primarily because they have a serious problem with their home's windows and doors. His house needs an urgent renovation to improve the insulation so the family can live a healthy and normal life. 

Kujtim is requesting a loan to renovate his house and to do the insulation of the house. He hopes this loan will improve the health of his family. Kujtim is very grateful to Kiva lenders for improving the family's conditions and standard of living!

loans.use: to renovate his house.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is a 44-year-old married woman and a mother of eight children from Ubay, Bohol. Judy has been engaged in a rice-farming business together with her husband for more than 20 years now. This is the source of their income.

Judy is asking for a loan to buy additional fertilizer and pesticides. With this loan, they will be able to improve and enhance their farm products. 

In the future, she has hopes of making her business a success and saving money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy additional fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric and his wife Gilaine moved from Mexico City to America looking for new opportunities and a better quality of life for their family. After only six months, Eric found himself unemployed after being laid off from the job that brought him to the US. Despite having a long work history with companies such as Microsoft, 3M and Time, he struggled to find work and took it as an opportunity to start his own business.

In October 2012, Eric and Gilaine started Llama Ink, a home-based digital printing company offering custom prints on any type of fabric.  With an enormous database of fun and innovative graphics, Llama Ink offers hundreds of pre-made custom design options for t-shirts, hoodies and tote bags. The company’s vision is to dress people with innovative products made in the USA, allowing them to express themselves in a fun and creative way, while supporting the local economy. 

Lacking the capital needed to get their company fully operational, the couple sought help from Accion San Diego, a local microlender.  Despite having no credit history, Eric was able to secure a $5,000 Kiva loan to be used to purchase equipment and invest in marketing and inventory. 

What Eric and Gilaine love most about their new venture is that it allows them to express their creativity, while working from home with their children. They hope to grow their business to the point where they can create new jobs, helping others who are where they once were. They also would like to give back to their community by donating a shirt for every shirt sold.  

Find Llama Ink online at: http://www.llamaink.com

loans.use: to purchase equipment and invest in marketing and inventory

loans.name: Ann. Beleswari Mahila Samiti Group

texts.en: Rina is a 35-year-old lady with three children. She lives in the Balipatna village of Odisha, India with her husband and her children. A few years back, she started growing vegetables and paddy. She grows different types of vegetable in her field depending upon the demand of her customers and the season. The group is requesting a loan of 260,000 INR. She will use her part to buy more supplies such as fertilizers, seeds, manure, etc. With this investment, she will expand her business so that she can generate more income and improve the quality of life for herself and her family. She is part of a group of 13 members, all of whom are women who live in the same community.  They named their group Ann. Beleswari Mahila Samiti, which is located in the Khurda district of Odisha, India.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, manure, etc

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen successfully completed her previous loan.  She is now requesting her second Loan from KADET LTD, which she will use to purchase more fish from various part of the country to resell.  She has decided to focus on selling fish, as her grocery business was not as profitable.  She is currently able to earn KES 20,000 from her fishmongering business. Hellen anticipates that she will use the profits to further expand her business.

Her dream is to buy land so that she can build her own home.

loans.use: to purchase fish for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Jamela

texts.en:
Jamela previously accessed a 30,000 PHP loan that she used to buy ready-to-wear products and merchandise to expand her inventory. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures. She is now requesting a 40,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies and products such as clothing, shirts, cellphone accessories, and other items needed in her business. 

The profits from her business will help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to increased profits with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.
Jamela hopes to be able to expand her business and dreams of having a good life with her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise such as clothing, cellphone accessories, and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is a 48-year-old married woman and a mother of four children from Bohol, Philippines. Merlinda earns a living through her mat weaving business. She has also been engaged in a rice farming business together with her husband for several years now.

Merlinda is asking for a loan to buy materials for mat weaving like romblon (pandanus leaves), dye/coloring and fertilzier for the farm. In the future, Merlinda hopes to make her business a success.

loans.use: to buy materials for mat weaving like romblon and dye/coloring and to buy fertilzier for the farm

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Worlanyo

texts.en: Worlanyo is a petty trader who hawks her wares (slippers and cooking utensils) at Alavanyo, Hohoe. Worlanyo has received a Junior High School education.  She is not married but has one child. Worlanyo has been selling since she dropped out of school last year. She is responsible for her personal general upkeep and that of the child. Her loan will be used to buy goods like slippers and cooking utensils so that she can make more profit. She hopes to save the profits from her business to get to more working capital.

loans.use: to buy goods like slippers and cooking utensils

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a thirty eight year old man.  He is married to his wife, Naomi, and is a father of four children.  He is a dairy farmer and also manages a rental property.  He has been in this business for twenty years.  His monthly income is 53,000 shillings.

This will be Francis's first loan with KADET LTD.  He plans to use the money to buy a dairy cow.  In the future, he wants to become a better businessman.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.
